entry.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
entry.summary: In a recent discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list, a member named Jonas Nick raised a concern regarding the blinding process in a signing protocol. He pointed out that without a blinding step, it is possible for a server (referred to as party 1) to learn the value of the hash c used in the signature verification process. By scanning the blockchain for signatures and computing the corresponding hashes, the server can compare them to the received hash c to obtain the preimage, including the original message m.To address this issue, moonsettler proposed a solution to the blinding problem. The proposed solution involves adding a blinding factor b to the equations used in the signing process. By introducing the blinding factor, the equation for the signature s becomes (k1 + k2 + b(x1 + x2)) + e(x1 + x2), where k1 and k2 are public keys, x1 and x2 are private keys, and e is the hash value obtained from the combination of R, X, and m.Moonsettler also provided a link to a GitHub gist containing the code implementation of the proposed solution. They expressed the need for a review of their solution and requested feedback from the community.It is worth noting that the context of the discussion revolves around the security and privacy aspects of the signing process in the bitcoin protocol. The proposed blinding mechanism aims to prevent the server from deducing the original message m by introducing additional variables and computations during the signing process. This discussion highlights the ongoing efforts to improve the privacy and security features of the bitcoin protocol.
